Title: Mapping Soil Properties in Tropical Rainforest Regions Using Integrated UAV-Based Hyperspectral Images and LiDAR Points
Authors: ['Chen, YQ', 'Shi, TZ', 'Li, QP', 'Yang, C', 'Wang, ZS', 'Chen, ZZ', 'Pan, XY']
Abstract: For tropical rainforest regions with dense vegetation cover, the development of effective large-scale soil mapping methods is crucial to improve soil management practices to replace the time-consuming and laborious conventional approaches. While machine learning (ML) algorithms demonstrate superior predictability of soil properties over linear models, their practical and automated application for predicting soil properties using remote sensing data requires further assessment. Therefore, this study aims to integrate Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs)-based hyperspectral images and Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) points to predict the soil properties indirectly in two tropical rainforest mountains (Diaoluo and Limu) in Hainan Province, China. A total of 175 features, including texture features, vegetation indices, and forest parameters, were extracted from two study sites. Six ML models, Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR), Random Forest (RF), Adaptive Boosting (AdaBoost), Gradient Boosting Decision Trees (GBDT), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP), were constructed to predict soil properties, including soil acidity (pH), total nitrogen (TN), soil organic carbon (SOC), and total phosphorus (TP). To enhance model performance, a Bayesian optimization algorithm (BOA) was introduced to obtain optimal model hyperparameters. The results showed that compared with the default parameter tuning method, BOA always improved models’ performances in predicting soil properties, achieving average R2 improvements of 202.93%, 121.48%, 8.90%, and 38.41% for soil pH, SOC, TN, and TP, respectively. In general, BOA effectively determined the complex interactions between hyperparameters and prediction features, leading to an improved model performance of ML methods compared to default parameter tuning models. The GBDT model generally outperformed other ML methods in predicting the soil pH and TN, while the XGBoost model achieved the highest prediction accuracy for SOC and TP. The fusion of hyperspectral images and LiDAR data resulted in better prediction of soil properties compared to using each single data source. The models utilizing the integration of features derived from hyperspectral images and LiDAR data outperformed those relying on one single data source. In summary, this study highlights the promising combination of UAV-based hyperspectral images with LiDAR data points to advance digital soil property mapping in forested areas, achieving large-scale soil management and monitoring.
Study site: Diaoluo Mountain (Lingshui County) and Limu Mountain (Qiongzhong County), Hainan Province, China
Spatial extent: Diaoluo study area 33.54 hm2; Limu study area 37.16 hm2
More on spatial study design: 4 (Diaoluo) and 23 (Limu) sampling sites; 3–4 quadrats per site (10 m × 10 m), 5 sampling points per quadrat; soil profiles split into 0–20 cm, 20–40 cm, 40–60 cm.
More on temporal study design: UAV data collected once across both mountains during that campaign.
Variables calculated: Soil organic carbon, Total nitrogen, Total Phosphorus, pH, Canopy Height Model, Hyperspectral indices
Other data included: Other data included: Field soil sampling + lab chemical analysis for SOC, TN, TP, pH (depth-stratified samples)
Objectives of the study: To integrate Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs)-based hyperspectral images and Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR) points to predict the soil properties indirectly in two tropical rainforest mountains (Diaoluo and Limu) in Hainan Province, China.
Key findings of the study: Achieved the high acurrracy of soil property prediction using UAV-based hyperspectral images combined with LiDAR data points, achieving average R2 improvements of 202.93%, 121.48%, 8.90%, and 38.41% for soil pH, SOC, TN, and TP, respectively.
Role of drone data in study: Drone hyperspectral and LiDAR provided canopy reflectance + 3D structure features used as predictors to indirectly estimate and map soil properties across the rainforest landscape.

Title: Enhanced flight planning and calibration for UAV based thermal imaging: implications for canopy temperature and transpiration analysis
Authors: ['Gerchow, M', 'K√ºhnhammer, K', 'Iraheta, A', 'Marshall, JD', 'Beyer, M']
Journal name: Frontiers in Forests and Global Change
Abstract: Leaf and canopy temperature have long been recognized as important indicators of plant water status because leaves cool when water is transpired and warm up when leaf stomata close and transpiration is reduced. Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) open up the possibility to capture high resolution thermal images of forest canopies at the leaf scale. However, a careful calibration procedure is required to convert the thermal images to absolute temperatures, in addition, at high spatial resolution, the complexity of forest canopies leads to challenges in stitching overlapping thermal images into an orthomosaic of the forest site. In this study, we present a novel flight planning approach in which the locations of ground temperature references are directly integrated in the flight plan. Six UAV flight campaigns were conducted over a tropical dry forest in Costa Rica. For each flight five different calibration methods were tested. The most accurate calibration was used to analyze the tree canopy temperature distributions of five tree species. From the distribution we correlated its mean, variance, 5th and 95th percentile against individual tree transpiration estimates derived from sapflow measurements. Our results show that the commonly applied calibration provided by the cameras manufacturer (factory calibration) and empirical line calibration were less accurate than the novel repeated empirical line calibration and the factory calibration including drift correction (MAE 3.5°C vs. MAE 1.5°C). We show that the orthomosaic is computable by directly estimating the thermal image orientation from the visible images during the structure from motion step. We found the 5th percentile of the canopy temperature distribution, corresponding to the shaded leaves within the canopy, to be a better predictor of tree transpiration than the mean canopy temperature (R2 0.85 vs. R2 0.60). Although these shaded leaves are not representative of the whole canopy, they may be the main transpiration site in the heat of the day. Spatially high-resolution, validated temperature data of forest canopies at the leaf scale have many applications for ecohydrological questions, e.g., the estimation of transpiration, for comparing plant traits and modeling of carbon and water fluxes by considering the entire canopy temperature distribution in mixed-species forests.
Study site: Estación Experimental Forestal Horizontes (Área de Conservación Guanacaste), northwest Costa Rica
More on temporal study design: Flights occurred at end of dry season / transition to rainy season; repeated reference captures roughly every minute enabled drift assessment and repeated recalibration during flights.
Other data included: Ground temperature references; Sap flow sensors on selected trees (to estimate transpiration / sap flow)
Objectives of the study: To develop and test a UAV flight-planning method that integrates ground temperature reference targets to improve absolute temperature calibration and thermal orthomosaic quality in forests.
Key findings of the study: Updated/repeated calibration approaches substantially reduced drift and error (validated MAE <1.3°C vs >3.5°C for non-updated methods); 5th percentile canopy temperature was a stronger predictor of sap flow than mean canopy temperature (reported R² ~0.85 vs ~0.60).
Role of drone data in study: High-resolution UAV thermal imagery enabled leaf-/canopy-scale temperature mapping (orthomosaics) and canopy temperature distribution statistics used to evaluate calibration performance, compare species, and relate temperatures to sap-flow-derived transpiration estimates.

Title: Distinguishing forest types in restored tropical landscapes with UAV-borne LIDAR
Authors: ['Scheeres, J', 'de Jong, J', 'Brede, B', 'Brancalion, PHS', 'Broadbent, EN', 'Zambrano, AMA', 'Gorgens, EB', 'Silva, CA', 'Valbuena, R', 'Molin, P', 'Stark, S', 'Rodrigues, RR', 'Rodrigues, R', 'Santoro, GB', 'de Almeida, CT', 'de Almeida, DRA']
Abstract: Forest landscape restoration is a global priority to mitigate negative effects of climate change, conserve biodiversity, and ensure future sustainability of forests, with international pledges concentrated in tropical forest regions. To hold restoration efforts accountable and monitor their outcomes, traditional strategies for monitoring tree cover increase by field surveys are falling short, because they are labor-intensive and costly. Meanwhile remote sensing approaches have not been able to distinguish different forest types that result from utilizing different restoration approaches (conservation versus production focus). Unoccupied Aerial Vehicles (UAV) with light detection and ranging (LiDAR) sensors can observe forests` vertical and horizontal structural variation, which has the potential to distinguish forest types. In this study, we explored this potential of UAV-borne LiDAR to distinguish forest types in landscapes under restoration in southeastern Brazil by using a supervised classification method. The study area encompassed 150 forest plots with six forest types divided in two forest groups: conservation (remnant forests, natural regrowth, and active restoration plantings) and production (monoculture, mixed, and abandoned plantations) forests. UAV-borne LiDAR data was used to extract several Canopy Height Model (CHM), voxel, and point cloud statistic based metrics at a high resolution for analysis. Using a random forest classification model we could successfully classify conservation and production forests (90% accuracy). Classification of the entire set of six types was less accurate (62%) and the confusion matrix showed a divide between conservation and production types. Understory Leaf Area Index (LAI) and the variation in vegetation density in the upper half of the canopy were the most important classification metrics. In particular, LAI understory showed the most variation, and may help advance ecological understanding in restoration. The difference in classification success underlines the difficulty of distinguishing individual forest types that are very similar in management, regeneration dynamics, and structure. In a restoration context, we showed the ability of UAV-borne LiDAR to identify complex forest structures at a plot scale and identify groups and types widely distributed across different restored landscapes with medium to high accuracy. Future research may explore a fusion of UAV-borne LiDAR with optical sensors, and include successional stages in the analyses to further characterize and distinguish forest types and their contributions to landscape restoration.
Study site: Atlantic Forest and Cerrado in southeastern Brazil
Sensor Model: Velodyne VLP-32c dual-return laser scanner (within the GatorEye Gen 2 / Phoenix Scout configuration)
More on spatial study design: Plots ≥60 m apart; ≥30 m from forest edge; avoid forested areas <1 ha where possible. LiDAR flight lines overlapped >50%; plots covered by 2–4 flight lines; average point density reported ~237 points/m² (and landscape-specific densities summarized)
More on temporal study design: LiDAR collected per landscape during the 27–29 Aug 2019 campaign; field plots were sampled between 2018 and 2020 (field inventory window differs from LiDAR campaign)
Variables calculated: Canopy Height Model, Canopy density, Leaf Area Index, Canopy height, Foliage Height Diversity, Leaf Area Height Volume
Objectives of the study: To evaluate whether UAV-LiDAR structural metrics can distinguish six forest types (and a simplified conservation vs production grouping) using supervised classification (Random Forest), and identify the most informative LiDAR metrics.
Key findings of the study: Random Forest classified conservation vs production with ~90% overall accuracy, while classification into six types achieved ~62% overall accuracy; LAI understory was the most important predictor (with canopy rugosity and dq60SD/hp50SD also important depending on model).
Role of drone data in study: UAV-LiDAR provided high-density 3D structural information enabling plot-scale extraction of canopy/understory metrics and subsequent forest-type classification across restoration mosaics.

Title: Use of Drone RGB Imagery to Quantify Indicator Variables of Tropical-Forest-Ecosystem Degradation and Restoration
Authors: ['Lee, KYH', 'Elliott, S', 'Tiansawat, P']
Abstract: Recognizing initial degradation levels is essential to planning effective measures to restore tropical forest ecosystems. However, measuring indicators of forest degradation is labour-intensive, time-consuming, and expensive. This study explored the use of canopy-height models and orthophotos, derived from drone-captured RGB images, above sites at various stages of degradation in northern Thailand to quantify variables related to initial degradation levels and subsequent restoration progression. Stocking density (R2 = 0.71) and relative cover of forest canopy (R2 = 0.83), ground vegetation (R2 = 0.71) and exposed soil + rock (R2 = 0.56) correlated highly with the corresponding ground-survey data. However, mean tree height (R2 = 0.31) and above-ground carbon density (R2 = 0.45) were not well correlated. Differences in correlation strength appeared to be site-specific and related to tree size distribution, canopy openness, and soil exposure. We concluded that drone-based quantification of forest-degradation indicator variables is not yet accurate enough to replace conventional ground surveys when planning forest restoration projects. However, the development of better geo-referencing in parallel with AI systems may improve the accuracy and cost-effectiveness of drone-based techniques in the near future.
Study site: Chiang Mai University’s Forest Restoration Research Unit, Thailand
More on spatial study design: 1.07 ha (BMSM); 1.03 ha (ML); 2.69 ha (BPK); 0.41 ha (BMM); 0.66 ha (LP). Total across sites = 5.86 ha.
Variables calculated: Canopy Cover, Canopy Height Model, Tree height, Tree Count, Above ground carbon density
Other data included: Ground surveys of tree height, girth at breast height (GBH), crown size; ocular estimates of ground vegetation and exposed soil/rock; climate context from meteorological stations; site history/restoration treatments.
Objectives of the study: To test whether a consumer drone with RGB imagery can generate CHMs/orthophotos from which degradation/restoration indicator variables can be quantified and used to distinguish degradation levels.
Key findings of the study: Drone-derived estimates correlated well with ground data for stocking density (R² 0.71) and cover variables (canopy cover R² 0.83; ground vegetation R² 0.71; exposed soil+rock R² 0.56), but were weak for mean tree height (R² 0.31) and ACD (R² 0.45); overall, drone-based quantification was not yet accurate enough to replace ground surveys for restoration planning
Role of drone data in study: Provided site-wide, high-resolution orthophotos and CHMs used to derive degradation/restoration indicator variables and compare them to conventional ground measurements.

Title: Comparison of Smartphone and Drone Lidar Methods for Characterizing Spatial Variation in PAI in a Tropical Forest
Authors: ['Rudic, TE', 'McCulloch, LA', 'Cushman, K']
Abstract: Estimating leaf area index (LAI) and assessing spatial variation in LAI across a landscape is crucial to many ecological studies. Several direct and indirect methods of LAI estimation have been developed and compared; however, many of these methods are prohibitively expensive and/or time consuming. Here, we examine the feasibility of using the free image processing software CAN-EYE to estimate effective plant area index (PAIeff) from hemispherical canopy images taken with an extremely inexpensive smartphone clip-on fisheye lens. We evaluate the effectiveness of this inexpensive method by comparing CAN-EYE smartphone PAIeff estimates to those from drone lidar over a lowland tropical forest at La Selva Biological Station, Costa Rica. We estimated PAIeff from drone lidar using a method based in radiative transfer theory that has been previously validated using simulated data; we consider this a conservative test of smartphone PAIeff reliability because above-canopy lidar estimates share few assumptions with understory image methods. Smartphone PAIeff varied from 0.1 to 4.4 throughout our study area and we found a significant correlation (r = 0.62, n = 42, p < 0.001) between smartphone and lidar PAIeff, which was robust to image processing analytical options and smartphone model. When old growth and secondary forests are assumed to have different leaf angle distributions for the lidar PAIeff algorithm (spherical and planophile, respectively) this relationship is further improved (r = 0.77, n = 42, p < 0.001). However, we found deviations in the magnitude of the PAIeff estimations depending on image analytical options. Our results suggest that smartphone images can be used to characterize spatial variation in PAIeff in a complex, heterogenous tropical forest canopy, with only small reductions in explanatory power compared to true digital hemispherical photography.
Study site: La Selva Biological Station, Costa Rica
UAV Model: BPAR (Brown Platform for Autonomous Remote Sensing; designed/operated by Aeroscout GmbH)
More on spatial study design: Two orthogonal sets of flight lines; 90 m above canopy; parallel lines 25 m apart (~90% overlap); flight speed 6 m/s; up to 6 returns/beam.
Temporal duration: LiDAR: 10–14 May 2019; smartphone hemispherical images: 15–22 May 2019
More on temporal study design: Smartphone images collected at dawn under diffuse light; images taken every 50 m along trail markers; LiDAR and smartphone timing chosen to reduce seasonal change.
Variables calculated: Canopy Height Model, Leaf Angle distribution, Leaf Area Index
Objectives of the study: To test feasibility of estimating effective Plant Area Index (PAIeff) from inexpensive smartphone fisheye images (CAN-EYE) and evaluate performance by comparison with drone LiDAR PAIeff across a heterogeneous tropical forest
Key findings of the study: Smartphone PAIeff correlated significantly with LiDAR PAIeff (reported r = 0.62, n = 42), improving when old-growth vs secondary forests used different leaf angle distributions in the LiDAR algorithm (reported r = 0.77)

Title: Top Canopy Height and Stem Size Variation Enhance Aboveground Biomass across Spatial Scales in Seasonal Tropical Forests
Authors: ['Sun, ZH', 'Sonsuthi, A', 'Jucker, T', 'Ali, A', 'Cao, M', 'Liu, F', 'Cao, GH', 'Hu, TY', 'Ma, Q', 'Guo, QH', 'Lin, LX']
Abstract: Tropical forests are biologically diverse and structurally complex ecosystems that can store a large quantity of carbon and support a great variety of plant and animal species. However, tropical forest structure can vary dramatically within seemingly homogeneous landscapes due to subtle changes in topography, soil fertility, species composition and past disturbances. Although numerous studies have reported the effects of field-based stand structure attributes on aboveground biomass (AGB) in tropical forests, the relative effects and contributions of UAV LiDAR-based canopy structure and ground-based stand structural attributes in shaping AGB remain unclear. Here, we hypothesize that mean top-of-canopy height (TCH) enhances AGB directly and indirectly via species richness and horizontal stand structural attributes, but these positive relationships are stronger at a larger spatial scale. We used a combined approach of field inventory and LiDAR-based remote sensing to explore how stand structural attributes (stem abundance, size variation and TCH) and tree species richness affect AGB along an elevational gradient in tropical forests at two spatial scales, i.e., 20 m × 20 m (small scale), and 50 m × 50 m (large scale) in southwest China. Specifically, we used structural equation models to test the proposed hypothesis. We found that TCH, stem size variation and abundance were strongly positively associated with AGB at both spatial scales, in addition to which increasing TCH led to greater AGB indirectly through increased stem size variation. Species richness had negative to negligible influences on AGB, but species richness increased with increasing stem abundance at both spatial scales. Our results suggest that light capture and use, modulated by stand structure, are key to promoting high AGB stocks in tropical forests. Thus, we argue that both horizontal and vertical stand structures are important for shaping AGB, but the relative contributions vary across spatial scales in tropical forests. Importantly, our results highlight the importance of including vertical forest stand attributes for predicting AGB and carbon sequestration that underpins human wellbeing.
Study site: tropical seasonal rain forests of Yunnan Province, China
More on spatial study design: Each plot subdivided into 20 m × 20 m quadrats (500 quadrats) and 50 m × 50 m quadrats (80 quadrats) to test scale dependence.
More on temporal study design: UAV LiDAR (Sept 2017) paired with the “latest” plot census (2017).
Other data included: Above ground biomass (AGB) per quadrat (scaled to Mg/ha) using pantropical allometry; wood density measured from cores; species richness (observed); stem size variation (CV of DBH).
Objectives of the study: To test whether TCH enhances AGB directly and indirectly (via richness and horizontal stand structure attributes), and whether these relationships are stronger at a larger spatial scale; evaluate relationships among stand structure, richness, elevation/topography, and AGB using structural equation models.
Key findings of the study: TCH, stem size variation, and stem abundance were strongly positively associated with AGB at both scales; increasing TCH also increased AGB indirectly via stem size variation; species richness had negative to negligible effects on AGB.
Role of drone data in study: UAV LiDAR provided the vertical canopy structure proxy (TCH) and supported terrain/elevation characterization used in the models linking stand structure/topography to AGB.
Associated data/imagery: Can be accessed by contacting the plot PI through ForestGEO Data Portal website (http://ctfs.si.edu/datarequest/).

Title: Strong temporal variation in treefall and branchfall rates in a tropical forest is related to extreme rainfall: results from 5 years of monthly drone data for a 50 ha plot
Authors: ['Araujo, RF', 'Grubinger, S', 'Celes, CHS', 'Negr√≥n-Ju√°rez, R', 'Garcia, M', 'Dandois, JP', 'Muller-Landau, HC']
Abstract: A mechanistic understanding of how tropical-tree mortality responds to climate variation is urgently needed to predict how tropical-forest carbon pools will respond to anthropogenic global change, which is altering the frequency and intensity of storms, droughts, and other climate extremes in tropical forests. We used 5 years of approximately monthly drone-acquired RGB (red–green–blue) imagery for 50 ha of mature tropical forest on Barro Colorado Island, Panama, to quantify spatial structure; temporal variation; and climate correlates of canopy disturbances, i.e., sudden and major drops in canopy height due to treefalls, branchfalls, or the collapse of standing dead trees. Canopy disturbance rates varied strongly over time and were higher in the wet season, even though wind speeds were lower in the wet season. The strongest correlate of monthly variation in canopy disturbance rates was the frequency of extreme rainfall events. The size distribution of canopy disturbances was best fit by a Weibull function and was close to a power function for sizes above 25 m2. Treefalls accounted for 74 % of the total area and 52 % of the total number of canopy disturbances in treefalls and branchfalls combined. We hypothesize that extremely high rainfall is a good predictor because it is an indicator of storms having high wind speeds, as well as saturated soils that increase uprooting risk. These results demonstrate the utility of repeat drone-acquired data for quantifying forest canopy disturbance rates at fine temporal and spatial resolutions over large areas, thereby enabling robust tests of how temporal variation in disturbance relates to climate drivers. Further insights could be gained by integrating these canopy observations with high-frequency measurements of wind speed and soil moisture in mechanistic models to better evaluate proximate drivers and with focal tree observations to quantify the links to tree mortality and woody turnover.
More on spatial study design: Orthomosaics + canopy surface models were generated via photogrammetry (Agisoft Metashape) for each date and then co-registered/aligned. Canopy disturbances were detected from differences between successive canopy surface models and visually verified using orthomosaics; automated pre-delineation used a >10 m canopy-height decrease, contiguous area ≥25 m², and area-to-perimeter ratio >0.6, followed by systematic manual editing across 1 ha subplots.
More on temporal study design: Canopy disturbance rates were standardized to percent area disturbed per month (per 30 d) and also computed as number of disturbances per ha per month; seasonality comparisons used defined dry vs wet season windows (dry season defined as 1 January–30 April; wet season May–December).
Variables calculated: Canopy Height Model, Forest cover, Tree fall, Branch fall, Canopy disturbance rate
Other data included: High-frequency meteorological data: rainfall (tipping bucket; recorded every 5 min, aggregated to 15 min) and wind speed (anemometer; 10 s measurements summarized to 15 min; maximum wind speeds used).
Objectives of the study: To quantify temporal variation in canopy disturbance rates and relate it to climate variation,  characterize disturbance size structure, and evaluate the role of branchfalls relative to treefalls.
Key findings of the study: Disturbance rates varied strongly through time and were higher in the wet season; the frequency of extreme rainfall events was the strongest correlate of monthly variation in disturbance rates, while maximum wind speed extremes were not significant; size distributions were best fit by a Weibull (and approximately power-law-like above 25 m²); treefalls accounted for most disturbed area while branchfalls were also common.
Role of drone data in study: Repeat drone RGB photogrammetry enabled spatially explicit detection and measurement of canopy height losses (disturbances) at fine spatial resolution over a large area (50 ha) and at near-monthly temporal resolution, enabling linkage of disturbance dynamics to extreme rainfall metrics.
Associated protocols: All orthomosaics, elevation models, and shapefiles are available at the Smithsonian Figshare repository https://doi.org/10.25573/data.c.5389043.v1 (Araujo et al., 2021b).
Associated data/imagery: Analysis codes, input data, and output results are available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5786740
Associated code: Analysis codes, input data, and output results are available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5786740

Title: Divergent seed dispersal outcomes: Interactions between seed, disperser, and forest traits
Authors: ['Dehaudt, B', 'Bruce, T', 'Deblauwe, V', 'Ferraz, A', 'Gardner, B', 'Bibila, TG', 'LeBreton, M', 'Mempong, G', 'Njabo, K', 'Nkengbeza, SN', 'Ordway, EM', 'Pavan, L', 'Russo, NJ', 'Smith, TB', 'Luskin, MS']
Abstract: Animals disperse seeds in various ways that affect seed deposition sites and seed survival, ultimately shaping plant species distribution, community composition, and ecosystem structure. Some animal species can disperse seeds through multiple pathways (e.g., defecation, regurgitation, epizoochory), each likely producing distinct seed dispersal outcomes. We studied how seed traits (size and toughness) interact with disperser species to influence seed dispersal pathway and how this ultimately shapes the proportion of seeds deposited in various habitat types. We focused on three frugivorous species of duikers (African forest antelopes) in the Dja Faunal Reserve, a tropical rainforest in southern Cameroon. Duikers can both defecate and regurgitate seeds, the latter predominantly occurring during rumination at their bedding sites (or “nests”). We located duiker nests and dungs along 18 linear 1-km-transects to assess: (1) how seed traits affect the likelihood of dispersal via defecation versus regurgitation, (2) if defecated versus regurgitated seeds are deposited at different rates in different forest types (assessed by indigenous Baka), microhabitats, and forest structural attributes (measured by drone lidar), and (3) if these differ between three duiker species that vary in size and diel activity patterns. We found that duikers predominantly defecated small seeds (<3 mm length) and regurgitated larger and tougher seeds (>10 mm length), the latter including 25 different plant species. The three duiker species varied in their nesting habits, with nocturnal bay duikers (Cephalophus dorsalis) nesting in dense understory vegetation at proportions 3–4 times higher than Peter's and yellow-backed duikers (Cephalophus callipygus and Cephalophus silvicultor). As a result, bay duikers deposited larger regurgitated seeds at a higher rate in habitats with denser understory where lianas and palms predominate and near fallen trees. This directed regurgitation seed deposition likely plays an important and unique role in forest succession and structure. This study highlights the importance of ungulate seed dispersal by regurgitation, a vastly understudied process that could impact many ecosystems given the prevalence of ruminating ungulates worldwide.
Variables calculated: Canopy Height Model, Canopy density, Leaf Area Index
Other data included: Nest/dung microhabitats; seed traits (size dimensions, toughness), seed IDs to species/morphospecies, pellet counts/sizes, and germination observations/trials.
Objectives of the study: To assess effects of seed traits on defecation vs regurgitation, whether deposition differs among forest types and structural attributes, and whether these patterns differ among three duiker species.
Key findings of the study: Duikers predominantly defecated small seeds (<3 mm) and regurgitated larger/tougher seeds (>10 mm); bay duikers nested disproportionately in dense understory and therefore deposited large regurgitated seeds more in dense-understory habitats near fallen trees, implying a distinct role in succession/structure.
Role of drone data in study: UAV-LiDAR provided 3D vegetation structure variables (canopy height, LAI, understory plant density, elevation) used to (a) compare structure among Baka-defined forest types and (b) run resource selection analyses of nesting/defecation site selection
Associated data/imagery: Data and code (Dehaudt, 2024) are available in figshare at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.26264246.
Associated code: Data and code (Dehaudt, 2024) are available in figshare at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.26264246.

Title: Species Classification in a Tropical Alpine Ecosystem Using UAV-Borne RGB and Hyperspectral Imagery
Authors: ['Garzon-Lopez, CX', 'Lasso, E']
Abstract: Páramos host more than 3500 vascular plant species and are crucial water providers for millions of people in the northern Andes. Monitoring species distribution at large scales is an urgent conservation priority in the face of ongoing climatic changes and increasing anthropogenic pressure on this ecosystem. For the first time in this ecosystem, we explored the potential of unoccupied aerial vehicles (UAV)-borne red, green, and blue wavelengths (RGB) and hyperspectral imagery for páramo species classification by collecting both types of images in a 10-ha area, and ground vegetation cover data from 10 plots within this area. Five plots were used for calibration and the other five for validation. With the hyperspectral data, we tested our capacity to detect five representative páramo species with different growth forms using support vector machine (SVM) and random forest (RF) classifiers in combination with three feature selection methods and two class groups. Using RGB images, we could classify 21 species with an accuracy greater than 97%. From hyperspectral imaging, the highest accuracy (89%) was found using models built with RF or SVM classifiers combined with a binary grouping method and the sequential floating forward selection feature. Our results demonstrate that páramo species can be accurately mapped using both RGB and hyperspectral imagery.
Study site: Parque Ecológico Matarredonda, eastern range of the Colombian Andes, Columbia
Sensor Model: RGB camera FC6310 (8.8 mm), Hyperspectral Headwall Hyperspec Nano VNIR 1003A-20502 (400–1000 nm; band width 2.2 nm) with GPS, IMU, and downwelling irradiance sensor (fodis)
More on spatial study design: RGB = 94 images; hyperspectral = 4 strips (images A–D), 272 bands; field plots were 10 permanent 1 m × 1 m plots plus 100 m² ground surveys around plots; plot coordinates recorded in WGS84
Other data included: Field vegetation data from permanent plots (species/genus IDs, mapped positions; WGS84), plus additional 100 m² ground surveys; GPS/IMU and downwelling irradiance (fodis) used for hyperspectral processing
Objectives of the study: To evaluate RGB (manual detection) and hyperspectral (supervised classification) UAV-borne data for species classification in páramo, and test modeling/feature-selection approaches to identify a reliable and replicable protocol
Key findings of the study: RGB imagery enabled classification of 21 species with accuracy >97%; hyperspectral classification achieved highest accuracy of 89% using RF or SVM with a binary grouping method and SFFS feature selection
Role of drone data in study: Provided high-resolution spatially continuous RGB and hyperspectral observations enabling species-level mapping/classification in a difficult-to-survey ecosystem

Title: Linking Drone and Ground-Based Liana Measurements in a Congolese Forest
Authors: ['Ka√ßamak, B', 'Barbier, N', 'Aubry-Kientz, M', 'Forni, E', 'Gourlet-Fleury, S', 'Guibal, D', 'Loumeto, JJ', 'Pollet, S', 'Rossi, V', 'Rowe, N', 'van Hoef, Y', 'R√©jou-M√©chain, M']
Journal name: Frontiers in Forests and Global Change
Abstract: Lianas are abundant and diverse in tropical forests and impact forest dynamics. They occupy part of the canopy, forming a layer of leaves overtopping tree crowns. Yet, their interaction with trees has been mainly studied from the ground. With the emergence of drone-based sensing, very high-resolution data may be obtained on liana distribution above canopies. Here, we assessed the relationship between common liana ground measurements and drone-determined liana leaf coverage over tree crowns, tested if this relationship is mediated by liana functional composition, and compared the signature of liana patches and tree crowns in our drone images. Using drone platforms, we acquired very high resolution RGB and multispectral images and LiDAR data over two 9-ha permanent plots located in northern Republic of Congo and delineated liana leaf coverage and individual tree crowns from these data. During a concomitant ground survey, we focused on 275 trees infested or not by lianas, for which we measured all lianas ≥ 1 cm in diameter climbing on them (n = 615) and estimated their crown occupancy index (COI). We additionally measured or recorded the wood density and climbing mechanisms of most liana taxa. Contrary to recent findings, we found significant relationships between most ground-derived metrics and the top-of-view liana leaf coverage over tree crowns. Tree crown infestation by lianas was primarily explained by the load of liana climbing on them, and negatively impacted by tree height. Liana leaf coverage over individual tree crowns was best predicted by liana basal area and negatively mediated by liana wood density, with a higher leaf area to diameter ratio for light-wooded lianas. COI scores were concordant with drone assessments, but two thirds differed from those obtained from drone measurements. Finally, liana patches had a higher light reflectance and variance of spectral responses than tree crowns in all studied spectra. However, the large overlap between them challenges the autodetection of liana patches in canopies. Overall, we illustrate that the joint use of ground and drone-based data deepen our understanding of liana-infestation pathways and of their functional and spectral diversity. We expect drone data to soon transform the field of liana ecology.
UAV Model: SenseFly eBee 03-907 (RGB, 2018/2019); DJI Mavic 2 Pro (RGB, 2020); DJI Matrice 600 (multispectral + LiDAR, 2020)
Sensor Model: GB: Hasselblad L1D-20c (20 MP) integrated camera on Mavic 2 Pro; Multispectral: Parrot Sequoia; LiDAR: YellowScan Surveyor Ultra (Velodyne Ultra Puck, 905 nm; Applanix 15 IMU)
Spatial resolution: Orthomosaics: 10 cm (2018 RGB), 5 cm (2019 RGB), 3 cm (2020 RGB), 17 cm (2020 multispectral). LiDAR products: 1 m DTM and 1 m CHM grid.
More on spatial study design: Core analysis extent: two 9-ha plots (18 ha total). Drone mapping extents reported for image products: 1292 ha (2018 RGB), 80 ha (2019 RGB), 56 ha (2020 RGB), 450 ha (2020 multispectral).
More on temporal study design: Within 2020: LiDAR 9 Feb 2020, multispectral 13 Feb 2020, RGB 14 Feb 2020.
Variables calculated: Canopy Height Model, Canopy Cover, Tree height
Other data included: Ground inventories (trees ≥10 cm dbh identified/located/measured annually since 2015 in plots); ground liana census (≥1 cm diameter on focal trees); wood density lab protocol for liana samples; site soils (Xanthic Acrisols) and rainfall summaries.
Objectives of the study: To quantify relationships between ground-based liana metrics and drone-based liana leaf coverage, test mediation by liana functional composition (wood density/climbing mechanism), evaluate COI accuracy, and compare spectral signatures of liana patches vs tree crowns.
Key findings of the study: Ground-derived metrics significantly relate to drone-based liana leaf coverage; liana basal area is the strongest predictor of leaf coverage; the relationship is negatively mediated by liana wood density (lighter-wooded lianas show higher leaf coverage); COI is broadly concordant but often mismatched vs drone estimates; liana patches have higher reflectance and higher spectral variance, but signatures overlap strongly with trees, complicating automated detection.
Role of drone data in study: Provided very high-resolution canopy view enabling delineation/quantification of liana leaf coverage and tree crowns (with LiDAR segmentation), and enabled spectral comparison between lianas and trees—used to validate/interpret ground liana metrics and COI.

Title: Scattered trees in an oil palm landscape: Density, size and distribution
Authors: ['Korol, Y', 'Khokthong, W', 'Zemp, DC', 'Irawan, B', 'Kreft, H', 'H√∂lscher, D']
Abstract: In tropical landscapes dominated by oil palm monocultures, scattered trees can contribute to biodiversity, regulate diverse ecosystem functions and deliver goods and services. However, basic quantitative information about such trees is often lacking. The objectives of our study were to identify the landscape-wide density and distribution patterns of scattered trees in an oil-palmdominated area of Sumatra (Indonesia), and to estimate their size. The study area with the total of 1120 ha was situated in Jambi province in the lowlands of Sumatra. In 2016, the year of our assessment, 83% of the area was covered by oil palm monocultures including industrial and smallholder plantations; other land-use types included rubber plantations and secondary forests. An earlier land-use classification suggests that oil palm cultivation began before 1990 on 41% of the area. The study area was mapped in 2016 using a fixed-wing drone equipped with red-greenblue and near-infrared cameras. We counted all visible trees in the aerial image. In the entire study region, we detected 10.1 scattered trees/ha. In areas where oil palm plantations were established before 1990, the tree density was 67% lower than in the area where oil palm was introduced later. The median tree crown diameter was 4.5 m, which corresponds to an estimated diameter at breast height of 12 cm; thus, most trees were small-statured. The trees were spatially clustered and often aligned along roads and rivers. In conclusion, we found a considerable number of scattered, mostly small-statured trees. This suggests that most trees were young and disappeared before reaching larger dimensions. To ensure the survival of trees and further provision of related ecosystem services, scattered trees in the oil palm landscape need to be conserved and/or restored.
Sensor Model: Canon PowerShot SX260 HS for RGB; same camera type with modified Rosco #2007 filter for NIR
More on spatial study design: Drone mission in Oct 2016; flight altitude 300 m a.s.l.; 50% side and 50% forward overlap; orthophotos generated/georeferenced in Agisoft; mosaics compiled and color-balanced (PCI Geomatica). Land-use map created by supervised maximum likelihood classification with ground-truthing (100 locations); map resampled to 10 m for land-use classification and accuracy assessment performed (504 reference points; 84% accuracy).
More on temporal study design: Land-use history inferred using a 1990 Landsat-based map (Melati 2017) to distinguish “SE-oil palm early” vs “NW-oil palm late,” and Google Earth Pro imagery (from 2002 onward) to classify plantation age (<15 vs ≥15 years in 2016).
Variables calculated: Tree Density, Tree Count, Canopy height, Tree Crown Diameter
Other data included: Satellite-based land-use history (Melati 2017; Landsat 1990), Google Earth time slices for plantation age, field ground-truthing points for land-use classification, and regression relationships based on prior studies (Harapan rainforest; EFForTS-BEE).
Objectives of the study: To identify density (n/ha) and spatial distribution of scattered trees; analyze crown structure/size, and discuss influence of land-use history.
Key findings of the study: Detected 10.1 scattered trees/ha across the region; density 67% lower where oil palm established before 1990; median crown diameter 4.5 m (mostly small trees); trees spatially clustered and often aligned along roads and rivers.
Role of drone data in study: Fixed-wing UAV RGB+NIR orthophotos enabled complete landscape-wide detection/counting of visible scattered trees, measurement of crown diameters, and assessment of spatial distribution across a 1120 ha oil palm landscape.

Title: An Approach for Detecting Mangrove Areas and Mapping Species Using Multispectral Drone Imagery and Deep Learning
Authors: ['Chen, XY', 'Zhang, XY', 'Zhuang, CW', 'Dai, XJ', 'Kong, LL', 'Xie, ZX', 'Hu, XB']
Abstract: Mangrove ecosystems are important in tropical and subtropical coastal zones, contributing to marine biodiversity and maintaining marine ecological balance. It is crucial to develop more efficient, intelligent, and accurate monitoring methods for mangroves to understand better and protect mangrove ecosystems. This study promotes a novel model, MangroveNet, for integrating multi-scale spectral and spatial information and detecting mangrove area. In addition, we also present an improved model, AttCloudNet+, to identify the distribution of mangrove species based on high-resolution multispectral drone images. These models incorporate spectral and spatial attention mechanisms and have been shown to effectively address the limitations of traditional methods, which have been prone to inaccuracy and low efficiency in mangrove species identification. In this study, we compare the results from MangroveNet with SegNet, UNet, and DeepUNet, etc. The findings demonstrate that the MangroveNet exhibits superior generalization learning capabilities and more accurate extraction outcomes than other deep learning models. The accuracy, F1_Score, mIoU, and precision of MangroveNet were 99.13%, 98.84%, 98.11%, and 99.14%, respectively. In terms of identifying mangrove species, the prediction results from AttCloudNet+ were compared with those obtained from traditional supervised and unsupervised classifications and various machine learning and deep learning methods. These include K-means clustering, ISODATA cluster analysis, Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machines (SVM), and others. The comparison demonstrates that the mangrove species identification results obtained using AttCloudNet+ exhibit the most optimal performance in terms of the Kappa coefficient and the overall accuracy (OA) index, reaching 0.81 and 0.87, respectively. The two comparison results confirm the effectiveness of the two models developed in this study for identifying mangroves and their species. Overall, we provide an efficient solution based on deep learning with a dual attention mechanism in the acceptable real-time monitoring of mangroves and their species using high-resolution multispectral drone imagery.
Study site: Zhanjiang Mangrove National Nature Reserve, China
More on spatial study design: 3726 multispectral images acquired Flight overlaps: 70% side, 80% forward Sensor elevation angle: −90° Orthophotos produced via Agisoft Metashape 2.1.1 (point cloud, DSM, orthophotos) Images/labels tiled into 512 × 512 px patches with 150 px overlap for model training Geo-correction described using five uniformly selected geographic feature control points
Other data included: Manual/expert labeling (thresholding + visual interpretation for mangrove extent; direct manual labeling for species categories) Field investigation used to confirm prevalent species in the training region (e.g., Rhizophora stylosa, Aegiceras corniculatum, Sonneratia apetala, Avicennia marina)
Objectives of the study: UAV-based high-resolution multispectral remote sensing + deep learning for mangrove extent detection and mangrove species mapping
Key findings of the study: MangroveNet performance reported as Accuracy 99.13%, F1 98.84%, mIoU 98.11%, Precision 99.14% AttCloudNet+ species mapping reported with Kappa 0.81 and Overall Accuracy 0.87 (and class-wise performance discussed in the conclusion)
Role of drone data in study: Provides the high-resolution multispectral imagery enabling (i) accurate mangrove extent extraction and (ii) species-level mapping that is difficult with coarser satellite imagery, supporting “real-time/near-real-time” monitoring goals as framed by the authors

Title: Effective integration of drone technology for mapping and managing palm species in the Peruvian Amazon
Authors: ['Casapia, XT', 'Cardenas-Vigo, R', 'Marcos, D', 'Gamarra, EF', 'Bartholomeus, H', 'Coronado, ENH', 'Porles, SD', 'Falen, L', 'Palacios, S', 'Tsenbazar, NE', 'Mitchell, G', 'Diaz, AD', 'Draper, FC', 'Llampazo, GF', 'Perez-Pena, P', 'Chipana, G', 'Torres, DD', 'Herold, M', 'Baker, TR']
Abstract: Remote sensing data could increase the value of tropical forest resources by helping to map economically important species. However, current tools lack precision over large areas, and remain inaccessible to stakeholders. Here, we work with the Protected Areas Authority of Peru to develop and implement precise, landscape-scale, species-level methods to assess the distribution and abundance of economically important arborescent Amazonian palms using field data, visible-spectrum drone imagery and deep learning. We compare the costs and time needed to inventory and develop sustainable fruit harvesting plans in two communities using traditional plot-based and our drone-based methods. Our approach detects individual palms of three species, even when densely clustered (average overall score, 74%), with high accuracy and completeness for Mauritia flexuosa (precision; 99% and recall; 81%). Compared to plot-based methods, our drone-based approach reduces costs per hectare of an inventory of Mauritia flexuosa for a management plan by 99% (USD 5 ha-1 versus USD 411 ha-1), and reduces total operational costs and personnel time to develop a management plan by 23% and 36%, respectively. These findings demonstrate how tailoring technology to the scale and precision required for management, and involvement of stakeholders at all stages, can help expand sustainable management in the tropics.
Study site: National Service of Protected Areas – SERNANP, Loreto, Peru
UAV Model: DJI Phantom 4 Pro, DJI Phantom 4 RTK, DJI Mavic 2
More on spatial study design: 80–90% forward/side overlap, mostly nadir camera angle (90°). Pix4DMapper used for mosaicking. 89 UAV mosaics total (training/validation set). Uses superpixel crown partitioning to delineate crowns and speed labeling; crown labels linked to GPS points; tiles of 512×512 px created; extensive data augmentation to improve generalisation.
More on temporal study design: Training/validation UAV data were collected concurrently with ground reference data. Flights intentionally varied in height to expose models to multiple spatial resolutions.
Variables calculated: Canopy Cover, Canopy Segmentation, Canopy density
Other data included: Ground reference GPS data for 5089 palms (3 species) with ~5 m average GPS error (2017–2019); some reference data from RAINFOR plots (via ForestPlots.net). Also includes SERNANP cost and personnel-time data for plot-based vs UAV-based inventory and management-plan workflows.
Objectives of the study: To automate detection and quantification of three palm species (Mauritia flexuosa, Oenocarpus bataua, Euterpe precatoria) using field data + RGB UAV mosaics + CNNs, and (ii) demonstrate a cost- and time-effective, implementable approach for SERNANP to build sustainable harvesting management plans.
Key findings of the study: Demonstrated species-level detection and individual counting over landscape scales (70–230 ha mosaics). Reported highest performance for Mauritia flexuosa (very high precision and strong recall relative to other species). UAV-based approach reduced inventory cost per hectare dramatically (plot-based vs UAV-based comparison) and reduced total operational costs and staff time for management plan development.
Role of drone data in study: Core data source enabling very-high-resolution, landscape-scale species mapping, crown delineation, and abundance estimation, supporting operational inventories used directly in management planning by the national protected areas authority.
Associated data/imagery: The UAV mosaics and their details can be found at 4TU ResearchData [https://doi.org/10.4121/70a8cec0-dfa7-4963-ba8a-612e738ec0cb.v1]
Associated code: The code for training the model and making predictions is available at Code Ocean [https://doi.org/10.24433/CO.0764353.v1]

Title: Comparison of RFE-DL and stacking ensemble learning algorithms for classifying mangrove species on UAV multispectral images
Authors: ['Fu, BL', 'He, X', 'Yao, H', 'Liang, YY', 'Deng, TF', 'He, HC', 'Fan, DL', 'Lan, GW', 'He, W']
Journal name: International Journal of Applied Earth Observation and Geoinformation
Abstract: Mangroves are highly productive wetland ecosystems, located at the interlocking area of tropical and subtropical coastal zones. Accurately mapping the distribution, quality and quantity of species are crucial for mangrove management, protection, and restoration. This study proposed a mangrove species mapping approach by combining recursive feature elimination (RFE) with deep learning (DL) algorithms, and further assess the effectiveness of feature selection for DL (DeeplabV3+ and PSPNet) algorithm to improve classification accuracy under the high dimensional UAV image datasets. We constructed an ensemble learning models (SEL) by stacking five base models (Random Forest, XGBoost, LightGBM, CatBoost, and AdaBoost), and evaluate the classification ability of mangrove species between SEL and RFE-DL algorithms. Comparison of the classifications of mangrove species was to evaluate the accuracy differences between SEL and base models. Results indicated that: (1) RFE algorithm could improve the classification accuracy of DL algorithms. RFE-DL models using the optimal features achieved 94.8% of overall accuracy (OA), which was 0.2%-8.5% higher than only using the original multispectral bands; (2) SEL algorithm produced better classification performance than RFE-DL with a higher 1.6%-12.7% of overall accuracy. Mcnemar’s test showed the classifications of mangrove species were significant differences between the three algorithms; (3) the SEL algorithm had a strong and stable ability for classifying mangrove species. The OA of six classification scenarios was from 75.5% to 92.2%, and the highest OA using SEL algorithm was 0.8%-4.2% higher than base models; (4) XGBoost algorithm had the highest importance, while AdaBoost had the lowest importance in the SEL-based classifications.
Sensor Model: RGB: Zenmuse X4S. Multispectral: MicaSense RedEdge MX
More on spatial study design: Main flights: 100 m AGL, 80% forward overlap and 80% side overlap, images every 3 s, acquisition window 10:00–15:00 (UTC+8), clear skies. 6 GCPs collected using V90 GPS-RTK; mosaicking/DSM/DOM in Pix4Dmapper with radiometric calibration using a MicaSense calibration target; low-overlap images (<70%) removed.
More on temporal study design: Field surveys conducted Nov 19–25 2020, Jan 08–14 2021, and Apr 04–16 2021; UAV imagery specifically collected Jan 08–13 2021.
Altitude Above Ground Level (AGL): 100 m (DJI Matrice 210 main imagery). 30 m (Phantom4-M transect imagery for visual interpretation)
Variables calculated: NDVI, NDWI, EVI, SAVI, Vegetation indices, Canopy Segmentation
Other data included: Ground reference data: 1866 samples across 8 classes (AM, KC, AC, Water body, Mudflat, Dead mangrove, Spartina alterniflora, Others) collected via 1 m × 1 m sampling squares with GPS-RTK and 9 low-altitude transect image sets; GCPs for photogrammetry.
Objectives of the study: Mangrove species mapping/classification using UAV multispectral imagery: comparison of RFE + deep learning (DeepLabV3+, PSPNet) vs stacking ensemble learning
Key findings of the study: (i) RFE improved DL accuracy (OA gains ~0.2%–9.8% vs using multispectral bands only); (ii) stacking ensemble achieved higher performance than RFE-DL overall (reported OA up to ~0.954 and 0.970 for two test sections; scenario-based stacking OA up to 0.922); (iii) multi-source feature fusion (VIs, texture, DSM) improved classification, with VIs and DSM particularly influential.
Role of drone data in study: Primary data source enabling (a) high-resolution multispectral/RGB mapping, (b) generation of DSM/DOM and derived features (VIs, textures), and (c) model training/validation for species-level mangrove and invasive species mapping.

Title: Estimation of mangrove heights and aboveground biomass using UAV-LiDAR, Sentinel-1 and ZY-3 stereo images
Authors: ['Fu, BL', 'Wei, YY', 'Jiang, LH', 'Yao, H', 'Li, XM', 'Yang, YL', 'Jia, MM', 'Sun, WW']
Abstract: Mangroves are crucial blue carbon ecosystems that are essential for promoting sustainable global development. Tree height is a key indicator of mangrove health; however, accurately estimating mangrove height in complex coastal environments is challenging. In this study, we constructed mangrove height inversion models using multiple types of remote sensing data and machine learning algorithms (partial least squares regression (PLSR), random forest (RF), and mixture density network (MDN)). We evaluated the performance of UAV-LiDAR point clouds, ZY-3 stereo images, and Sentinel-1 polarimetric and interferometric data in mangrove height inversion, and explored the accuracy differences among the dominant species. We also estimated the aboveground biomass of different dominant mangrove species to better understand their ecological functions and health conditions. The results showed the following: (1) The canopy height model and height variables of the LiDAR point clouds, DVI and near-infrared bands of the ZY-3 stereo images, and polarimetric decomposition parameters of the Sentinel-1 SAR images were more sensitive to mangrove heights. (2) The LiDAR point clouds and Sentinel-1 SAR images achieved the highest inversion accuracy when using the RF algorithm, with R2 values of 0.875 and 0.685, respectively. The ZY-3 stereo images based on MDN obtained the optimal inversion results (R2 = 0.719), with an improvement ranging from 0.143 to 0.198 when compared to the PLSR and RF algorithms. (3) Avicennia marina was associated with the highest estimation accuracy (R2 = 0.897) compared to the other dominant mangrove species. Aegiceras corniculatum and Avicennia marina were associated with the highest inversion accuracy within the height range of 2–3 m (R2 = 0.925, R2 = 0.814, respectively), whereas Kandelia candel yielded the optimal inversion results at the height range of 1–2 m (R2 = 0.652). (4) The aboveground biomass of Aegiceras cornicatum and Kandelia candel ranged from 20.176 to 103.164 Mg/ha and 132.019 to 719.226 Mg/ha, respectively, and the aboveground biomass of Avicennia marina was mainly distributed within the range of 169.916 to 803.204 Mg/ha. Our study provides a reference for monitoring the heights and health of mangroves, as well as their protection and development.
Variables calculated: Canopy Height Model, Canopy height, Biomass Estimation
Other data included: Field-measured tree heights and crown breadths for three dominant species (total 408 sample points) + RTK GPS coordinates for sample locations.
Objectives of the study: Estimating mangrove canopy/tree height (and biomass) using multi-source remote sensing and machine learning, with evaluation across dominant species and height gradients.
Key findings of the study: Avicennia marina achieved highest height-estimation accuracy (reported R² = 0.897) using LiDAR point clouds.
Role of drone data in study: UAV LiDAR point clouds are a primary data source for height inversion and for downstream AGB estimation/mapping, and are benchmarked against other platforms (ZY-3 stereo; Sentinel-1 SAR).

Title: Biomass Estimation Using 3D Data from Unmanned Aerial Vehicle Imagery in a Tropical Woodland
Authors: ['Kachamba, DJ', 'Orka, HO', 'Gobakken, T', 'Eid, T', 'Mwase, W']
Abstract: Application of 3D data derived from images captured using unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in forest biomass estimation has shown great potential in reducing costs and improving the estimates. However, such data have never been tested in miombo woodlands. UAV-based biomass estimation relies on the availability of reliable digital terrain models (DTMs). The main objective of this study was to evaluate application of 3D data derived from UAV imagery in biomass estimation and to compare impacts of DTMs generated based on different methods and parameter settings. Biomass was modeled using data acquired from 107 sample plots in a forest reserve in miombo woodlands of Malawi. The results indicated that there are no significant differences (p = 0.985) between tested DTMs except for that based on shuttle radar topography mission (SRTM). A model developed using unsupervised ground filtering based on a grid search approach, had the smallest root mean square error (RMSE) of 46.7% of a mean biomass value of 38.99 Mg·ha−1. Amongst the independent variables, maximum canopy height (Hmax) was the most frequently selected. In addition, all models included spectral variables incorporating the three color bands red, green and blue. The study has demonstrated that UAV acquired image data can be used in biomass estimation in miombo woodlands using automatically generated DTMs.
More on spatial study design: Flight planning in eMotion 2 (v2.4) using Bing basemap; 4 flight blocks over 4 days; side overlap 90% and forward overlap 80%; flight height 325 m; image counts per day/block reported
More on temporal study design: Flights executed as multiple blocks per day across the 4-day window
Other data included: Ground reference biomass/field plot data and external elevation information from SRTM for improving terrain modeling
Objectives of the study: Estimating aboveground biomass in miombo woodlands using UAV SfM point clouds, with emphasis on digital terrain model (DTM) generation in tropical forests
Key findings of the study: AGB estimation achieved relative RMSE around 32.43%, improving to 31.98% when external SRTM heights were used for DTM support. Most suitable DTM approach (in the reported conclusion) involved supervised classification, and SRTM-based terrain information improved results.
Role of drone data in study: UAV imagery enabled SfM reconstruction of 3D point clouds used to derive canopy structure metrics and build AGB models; it also allowed testing DTM-generation strategies relevant when ground points are sparse/absent

Title: You Can Bend Me but Can't Break Me: Vegetation Regeneration After Hurricane Maria Passed Over an Urban Coastal Wetland in Northeastern Puerto Rico
Authors: ['Hern√°ndez, E', 'Cuevas, E', 'Pinto-Pacheco, S', 'Ort√≠z-Ram√≠rez, G']
Abstract: Tropical urban coastal wetland regeneration is complex. Wetland plant biodiversity varies due to past and present land use, nutrient inputs, hydrological conditions, and terrestrial/marine connectivity. The intensity of atmospheric disturbances, such as hurricanes, will determine these systems’ level of disturbance and regeneration capacity. On September 20, 2017, category 4 hurricane María passed over Puerto Rico, leaving behind a path of destruction across the entire island, especially in coastal ecosystems, from the combined effects of winds, severe storm surges, and urban runoff. Our question was: to what extent do human-influenced coastal urban wetlands regenerate after such a massive event. This study determines the spatio-temporal regeneration dynamics of plant cover and composition during the first 2 years after hurricane María in a coastal urban wetland, ciénaga Las Cucharillas, located in San Juan Bay. We assessed the distribution of plant functional types using small unmanned aerial vehicles (s-UAV) and monitored climate and environmental data (salinity, phreatic water levels, and precipitation). Wetland vegetation cover had a high recovery rate – 16 months after the hurricane, vegetation cover occupied 87% of the study area. We found a successional pattern of plant regeneration that seemed to be partly explained by the fast-slow continuum. Plants with high specific leaf area (SLA) colonized bare soil spaces first. Plant regeneration also varied according to changes in phreatic water conductivity and waterlogging. Isotopic analyses of plant species signaled high nutrient availability, increasing the system’s regeneration speed. After 2 years, the wetland’s plant cover and composition of functional plant types proved resilient to the initial hurricane effect and subsequent changes in conductivity and freshwater conditions. Further studies will expand how spatio-temporal conditions will affect long-term plant community dynamics.
Study site: Ciénaga Las Cucharillas natural reserve (San Juan Bay), northern metropolitan area of Puerto Rico
More on spatial study design: Orthomosaics analyzed in ArcGIS Pro; land-cover polygons digitized manually then rasterized for pixel-by-pixel comparisons
Variables calculated: Visible Atmospherically Resistant Index, Forest cover, Land Cover
Other data included: Environmental monitoring: precipitation; phreatic water conductivity and water levels (10 wells); microtopography from USGS 10 m DEM; plant traits (leaf area, dry mass, SLA), stable isotopes (δ13C, δ15N), derived intrinsic WUE; species collections and herbarium-based identification support.
Objectives of the study: Determine spatio-temporal regeneration dynamics of plant cover and composition during the first 2 years after Hurricane María; assess distribution of plant functional types using s-UAV and relate regeneration to climate/environmental conditions (salinity/conductivity, water levels, precipitation).
Key findings of the study: Vegetation cover recovered rapidly: 16 months post-hurricane, vegetation covered 87% of the study area; regeneration followed a successional pattern where high-SLA colonizers occupied bare soil first; regeneration varied with phreatic conductivity and waterlogging; isotopes suggested high nutrient availability accelerating recovery; after 2 years, cover and functional-type composition were resilient to the initial hurricane and subsequent hydrologic changes.
Role of drone data in study: UAV RGB imagery enabled repeated high-resolution mapping of land-cover/functional-type distribution and quantification of vegetation recovery trajectories (including VARI and cover-area changes) across post-hurricane time points.

Title: TROPICAL FOREST DISASTER MONITORING WITH MULTI-SCALE SENSORS FROM TERRESTRIAL LASER, UAV, TO SATELLITE RADAR
Authors: ['Kato, A', 'Wakabayashi, H', 'Hayakawa, Y', 'Bradford, M', 'Watanabe, M', 'Yamaguchi, Y']
Abstract: Forest disaster monitoring requires frequent data observation of remotely sensed data. It is getting more common to use open satellite image archives to monitor land use change from multi-temporal data. In this study, multi-temporal DSM created by UAV-SfM is used to identify forest gap. ALOS 2 full polarization data is compared with the finer scale height difference detected by multi-temporal UAV based DSMs. Advantage of UAV based observation is to identify forest gap area efficiently in wide area and collect more samples to compare wide coverage of the satellite radar backscatter to understand backscatter characteristics. As a result, HH and HV polarization has detection power of forest gap size.
Study site: Robson Creek tropical forest in Australia
More on spatial study design: 25 ha plot divided into 1 ha units; TLS acquired at centers of each 1 ha plot (25 locations).
More on temporal study design: PALSAR-2 acquired May 2016; TLS acquired in 2015 and 2016; DTM from airborne laser data acquired 2014 used as terrain reference for canopy height estimation (DSM–DTM → DCM).
Other data included: TLS (RIEGL VZ400) collected 2015 & 2016; field tree heights using Vertex 3 (Haglof) for accuracy assessment; PALSAR-2 full-pol SAR (3.125 m resolution, topographically corrected sigma naught); airborne lidar (2014) for DTM reference.
Objectives of the study: Use multi-temporal UAV-SfM DSMs to identify forest gaps and compare these fine-scale height changes with ALOS-2/PALSAR-2 full-polarimetric backscatter to understand polarization characteristics over forest gaps (natural disturbance).
Key findings of the study: HV backscatter was the most sensitive to forest gap size; HH also detected height difference/gap conditions. UAV DSMs provided an efficient “ground truth” approach for validating/interpreting satellite radar over unpredictable disturbance events.
Role of drone data in study: UAV-SfM produced high-resolution DSMs (10 cm) enabling forest gap detection via inter-annual height differencing; these gap metrics were used to sample/interpret PALSAR-2 polarization backscatter at corresponding locations (UAV as the fine-scale structural benchmark).

Title: ReforesTree: A Dataset for Estimating Tropical Forest Carbon Stock with Deep Learning and Aerial Imagery
Authors: ['Reiersen, G', 'Dao, D', 'L√ºtjens, B', 'Klemmer, K', 'Amara, K', 'Steinegger, A', 'Zhang, C', 'Zhu, XX']
Abstract: Forest biomass is a key influence for future climate, and the world urgently needs highly scalable financing schemes, such as carbon offsetting certifications, to protect and restore forests. Current manual forest carbon stock inventory methods of measuring single trees by hand are time, labour, and cost intensive and have been shown to be subjective. They can lead to substantial overestimation of the carbon stock and ultimately distrust in forest financing. The potential for impact and scale of leveraging advancements in machine learning and remote sensing technologies is promising, but needs to be of high quality in order to replace the current forest stock protocols for certifications. In this paper, we present ReforesTree, a benchmark dataset of forest carbon stock in six agro-forestry carbon offsetting sites in Ecuador. Furthermore, we show that a deep learning-based end-to-end model using individual tree detection from low cost RGB-only drone imagery is accurately estimating forest carbon stock within official carbon offsetting certification standards. Additionally, our baseline CNN model outperforms state-of-the-art satellite-based forest biomass and carbon stock estimates for this type of small-scale, tropical agro-forestry sites. We present this dataset to encourage machine learning research in this area to increase accountability and transparency of monitoring, verification and reporting (MVR) in carbon offsetting projects, as well as scaling global reforestation financing through accurate remote sensing.
More on spatial study design: RGB orthomosaics were cut into 4000×4000 tiles; tiles processed for crown detection and label matching (DeepForest + OneForest pipeline).
More on temporal study design: Sites contain banana/cacao planted 2016–2019; drone imagery and inventory were conducted in 2020.
Variables calculated: Above ground biomass, Diamater breast height
Other data included: Manual forest inventory per tree includes GPS location, species, DBH; the workflow also creates per-tree bounding boxes from orthomosaics and includes banana vs. non-banana labels.
Objectives of the study: Estimating tropical agroforestry forest carbon stock using low-cost RGB drone imagery plus deep learning (individual-tree detection + biomass estimation).
Key findings of the study: The paper reports that an end-to-end deep learning approach using RGB-only drone imagery can estimate forest carbon stock within certification standards, and their baseline model compares favorably against existing global/satellite biomass maps for these small-scale tropical sites.
Role of drone data in study: Drone RGB imagery provided the high-resolution input for individual tree crown detection and creation of per-tree training labels (bounding boxes) used to estimate individual-tree AGB and aggregate carbon stock.

Title: Composition, structure and regeneration strategy of Campnosperma panamense (Anacardiaceae) swamp forests in Darien, Panama
Authors: ['Ib√°√±ez, A', 'Ba√∫les, A', 'Venegas, MA', 'S√°nchez, C', 'Flores, R', 'Candanedo, I']
Abstract: Introduction: Orey swamp forests (Campnosperma panamense) are found on the Caribbean coast of Central America, from Nicaragua to Panama, and in the Pacific of Colombia to Northern Ecuador. In Panama, orey grows in monospecific stands or is the dominant species in inundated mixed forests, mainly along the coasts of Bocas del Toro province and Comarca Ngäbe-Buglé. The species was known to occur in Darien province, in the Pacific, although almost no information on its distribution and forest extension in the region existed. Objective: To describe the structure and floristics of orey forests in Darien, map their extension, and propose a model for their regeneration strategy. Methods: This work is part of a vegetation mapping project of the Matusagaratí complex of wetlands. It includes the use of drones, ground truthing, vegetation sampling through temporary plots, and general plant collecting. A supervised classification of a Landsat satellite image was performed to delimit the orey forest extension. To study the orey forest regeneration strategy, a digitalization of forest gaps in high resolution WorldView-2 and Planet Scope images over years was performed. Gap frequency and turnover time for forest stands were calculated. Results: Several monospecific orey mature forest patches were found in remote areas of the Matusagaratí complex of wetlands, for a total of 1 267 hectares. A description of the floristics and structure of orey forests in Darien is presented. A conceptual model of orey mature forest development and gap regeneration is proposed. Conclusions: Our knowledge of the floristic composition, structure and distribution of orey forests in the Republic of Panama has increased. For the first time, a model about their regeneration strategy is proposed. These forests seem to be evolving to different formations. Finally, some hypotheses are proposed about how they might respond to changing environmental conditions.
Study site: Matusagaratí complex of wetlands, in Darien Province, Pacific Panama
More on spatial study design: Field sampling: three 0.1 ha plots (20 × 50 m) in mature orey forest (Balsas River near “Cacerete”). Gap mapping: digitized gaps in the 2.93 km² site using WorldView-2 (initial) and PlanetScope (time series), in ArcGIS Pro; images georeferenced prior to analyses.

Other data included: Field ground-truthing of vegetation types/dominant species; vegetation inventories in plots (mapped/measured stems ≥5 cm DBH); voucher specimens verified at University of Panama herbarium (PMA).
Objectives of the study: Describe structure/floristics of orey forests in Darién, map their extension, and propose a regeneration-strategy model (gap-based)
Key findings of the study: Several mature orey forest patches identified totaling 1 267 hectares; plot inventories recorded 447 individuals (815 stems) in 0.3 ha with 13 species, and strong dominance by Campnosperma panamense and Euterpe oleracea
Role of drone data in study: Drone used for filming/photographing ecosystems/vegetation types and documenting gap formation/regeneration stages; paired with ground truthing to corroborate dominant species (drone not used for quantitative spatial products in this paper).

Title: COLI: a synergy index for optical and LiDAR synergy estimation for aboveground biomass of urban trees
Authors: ['Bai, LZ', 'Hu, B', 'Wang, K']
Abstract: The estimation of aboveground biomass (AGB) of urban trees is crucial for exploring urban carbon cycling and sustainable development. Optical remote sensing is the most widely used data for AGB estimation, and its performance is limited by saturation effects. In contrast, LiDAR can reflect the three-dimensional features of trees, but lacks spectral information. Therefore, the objective of this study is to devise a methodology for estimating the AGB of urban trees by integrating optical and LiDAR data. Taking Hengqin New Area in China as a case study, this study presents a novel synergy index COLI through a meticulous optimization and sensitivity analysis of optical and LiDAR features, and thoroughly explores the performance of COLI. Subsequently, this study used four estimation models (Deep Belief Networks (DBN), Stacked Sparse Autoencoder networks (SSAE), Random Forest (RF) and Support Vector Machine Regression (SVR)) and set up multiple sets of experimental variables for validation. The results indicate that: (1) Our proposed COLI index can significantly improve the accuracy of optical and LiDAR variable estimation of AGB (2) The SSAE model has optimal modelling performance for various variable settings. The R2 of the SSAE model using a combination of optical, LiDAR, and COLI variables is 0.801, and the relative Root Mean Square Error (RMSEr) is 14.92%. These findings suggest that the proposed workflow has the potential to emerge as a potent tool for the AGB estimation of urban trees.
Study site: Hengqin, the southern – China Great Bay Area, China
More on spatial study design: not reported
More on temporal study design: Field measurements (2018) and optical imagery (2018) were used alongside later UAV-LiDAR (2023) for structural mapping and modelling
Variables calculated: Canopy Height Model, Vegetation indices, Canopy Cover, Canopy leaf ratio, Texture indices
Other data included: Field inventory data per plot (H, DBH, species) and derived AGB; AGB computed from allometric equation using H and DBH
Objectives of the study: Develop an approach to estimate urban-tree AGB by integrating optical + LiDAR data; propose and evaluate the COLI synergy index; validate multiple modelling approaches
Key findings of the study: COLI improved AGB estimation when combining optical and LiDAR predictors, Best-performing configuration: SSAE with optical + LiDAR + COLI achieved R² = 0.801 and RMSEr = 14.92%, COLI had the highest variable importance in their RF importance analysis (0.173), Wall-to-wall AGB mapping (within LiDAR coverage): max 285.37 Mg/ha, mean 90.02 Mg/ha
Role of drone data in study: UAV-LiDAR provided 3D canopy structure used to generate a CHM and LiDAR-derived structural predictors, enabling improved AGB estimation and spatial AGB mapping beyond saturation limits of optical-only predictors

Title: From Coastal to Montane Forest Ecosystems, Using Drones for Multi-Species Research in the Tropics
Authors: ['Rahman, DA', 'Sitorus, ABY', 'Condro, AA']
Abstract: Biodiversity monitoring is crucial in tackling defaunation in the Anthropocene, particularly in tropical ecosystems. However, field surveys are often limited by habitat complexity, logistical constraints, financing and detectability. Hence, leveraging drones technology for species monitoring is required to overcome the caveats of conventional surveys. We investigated prospective methods for wildlife monitoring using drones in four ecosystems. We surveyed waterbird populations in Pulau Rambut, a community of ungulates in Baluran and endemic non-human primates in Gunung Halimun-Salak, Indonesia in 2021 using a DJI Matrice 300 RTK and DJI Mavic 2 Enterprise Dual with additional thermal sensors. We then, consecutively, implemented two survey methods at three sites to compare the efficacy of drones against traditional ground survey methods for each species. The results show that drone surveys provide advantages over ground surveys, including precise size estimation, less disturbance and broader area coverage. Moreover, heat signatures helped to detect species which were not easily spotted in the radiometric imagery, while the detailed radiometric imagery allowed for species identification. Our research also demonstrates that machine learning approaches show a relatively high performance in species detection. Our approaches prove promising for wildlife surveys using drones in different ecosystems in tropical forests.
